title: Ōgaki
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Gifu%20Prefecture">Gifu</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 161,539, and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 782 persons per km2 in 65,931 households. The total area of the city was . Ōgaki was the final destination for the haiku poet <a href="Matsuo%20Bash%C5%8D">Matsuo Bashō</a> on one of his long journeys as recounted in his book "<a href="Oku%20no%20Hosomichi">Oku no Hosomichi</a>". Every November the city holds a Bashō Festival.
Geography.
Ōgaki is located in the northwest area of the <a href="N%C5%8Dbi%20Plain">Nōbi Plain</a> in Gifu Prefecture and is known as being the most centrally-located city in Japan. As a result of its 2006 merger with the town of <a href="Kamiishizu%2C%20Gifu">Kamiishizu</a> (from <a href="Y%C5%8Dr%C5%8D%20District%2C%20Gifu">Yōrō District</a>), and the town of <a href="Sunomata%2C%20Gifu">Sunomata</a> (from <a href="Anpachi%20District%2C%20Gifu">Anpachi District</a>), the city consists of three disconnected regions, with Sunomata in the east, the original Ōgaki in the center, and Kamiishizu in the southwest.
The main river flowing through the city is the <a href="Ibi%20River">Ibi River</a>; however, the <a href="Nagara%20River">Nagara River</a> forms the border between Ōgaki and the neighboring cities of <a href="Gifu%2C%20Gifu">Gifu</a> and <a href="Hashima%2C%20Gifu">Hashima</a>.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Ōgaki has increased gradually over the past 40 years.
Climate.
The city has a climate characterized by characterized by hot and humid summers, and mild winters (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "Cfa"). The average annual temperature in Ōgaki is 14.8 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1871 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 27.2 °C, and lowest in January, at around 3.7 °C.
History.
The area around Ōgaki was part of traditional <a href="Mino%20Province">Mino Province</a>. During the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>, the area developed as a <a href="castle%20town">castle town</a> for <a href="%C5%8Cgaki%20Domain">Ōgaki Domain</a> under the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a>. In the post-<a href="Meiji%20restoration">Meiji restoration</a> cadastral reforms, the town of Ogaki was established within <a href="Anpachi%20District%2C%20Gifu">Anpachi District</a>, Gifu Prefecture with the creation of the modern municipalities system on July 1, 1889. It was raised to city status on April 1, 1918. The city suffered severe flooding during the <a href="1934%20Muroto%20typhoon">1934 Muroto typhoon</a>, and was largely destroyed in six air raids in 1945.
Government.
Ōgaki has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city legislature of 22 members.
Economy.
<a href="Ibiden">Ibiden</a>, a global electronic components manufacturer, is headquartered in the city.
Education.
Primary and secondary education.
Ōgaki has 22 public elementary schools and ten public middle schools operated by the city government and one private middle school. The city has nine public high school operated by the Gifu Prefectural Board of Education, and two private high schools. The prefecture also operates one special education school.
